text: Which financial services sub-sector does this AI system operate in?

options.label: Banking
options.description: Retail or commercial banking, deposit services

options.label: Insurance
options.description: Life, health, property, or casualty insurance

options.label: Investment / asset management
options.description: Investment advisory, portfolio management, fund management

options.label: Payments
options.description: Payment processing, digital wallets, money transfer

options.label: Lending
options.description: Consumer or commercial lending, mortgage origination

regulatoryRelevance: Financial sub-sector determines which specific regulatory bodies and frameworks apply (MAS, FCA, OCC, SEC) and influences risk classification under the EU AI Act.

text: Does the system assess creditworthiness or make credit-related decisions?
regulatoryRelevance: Credit scoring and creditworthiness assessment is classified as HIGH-RISK under EU AI Act Annex III ยง5. Triggers full conformity assessment, CFPB fair lending requirements (ECOA/Reg B), and MAS model risk management.

text: Does the system assess insurance risk or determine insurance pricing (premiums)?
regulatoryRelevance: Life and health insurance risk assessment and pricing is classified as HIGH-RISK under EU AI Act Annex III ยง5. Triggers conformity assessment requirements and state insurance regulator scrutiny in the US.

text: Does the system perform algorithmic trading, automated order execution, or market-related decisions?
regulatoryRelevance: Algorithmic trading triggers MiFID II requirements in the EU, SEC oversight in the US, and MAS requirements in Singapore. Risk controls and human oversight are mandatory.

text: Does the system perform AML (Anti-Money Laundering) screening, KYC (Know Your Customer) verification, or suspicious activity detection?
regulatoryRelevance: AML/KYC AI systems must comply with financial crime regulations across all jurisdictions. Model accuracy and false positive rates are scrutinized by regulators. MAS and FCA provide specific guidance.

text: Which financial regulatory bodies supervise your institution? Select all that apply.

options.label: OCC (US)
options.description: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

options.label: Federal Reserve (US)
options.description: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System

options.label: EIOPA (EU)
options.description: European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority

regulatoryRelevance: Identifying supervising regulatory bodies determines which sector-specific AI governance requirements apply in addition to general AI regulations. Each regulator has distinct expectations for model risk management.

text: Does your institution have a model risk governance framework in place (e.g., compliant with OCC/Fed SR 11-7 or MAS model risk management guidelines)?
regulatoryRelevance: SR 11-7 (OCC/Fed) requires financial institutions to have comprehensive model risk management. MAS AI Risk Management Guidelines require governance frameworks, lifecycle controls, and materiality assessments for AI models.

text: Has a materiality assessment been conducted to evaluate the risk significance of this AI use case within your institution?
regulatoryRelevance: MAS AI Risk Management Guidelines specifically require financial institutions to conduct materiality assessments of AI use cases to determine proportionate governance controls.

text: Can the system provide meaningful explanations of its decisions to affected customers (e.g., why a loan was denied, why a premium was set at a certain level)?
regulatoryRelevance: ECOA/Reg B requires adverse action notices with specific reasons for credit denials. GDPR Article 22 requires meaningful information about automated decision logic. MAS expects explainability for customer-facing AI decisions.
